1using System;
2using System.Collections.Generic;
3​
4namespace TechnicalIndicators
5{
6 /// <summary>
7 /// Average Directional Index (ADX)
8 /// </summary>
9 /// <remarks>
10 /// Measures the strength of a trend, regardless of its direction.
11 /// <list type="bullet">
12 /// <item><description>+DI: Positive Directional Indicator (Bullish strength).</description></item>
13 /// <item><description>-DI: Negative Directional Indicator (Bearish strength).</description></item>
14 /// <item><description>ADX: Average Directional Index (Smoothed strength of the trend).</description></item>
15 /// </list>
16 /// </remarks>
17 public class AverageDirectionalIndex
18 {
19 public int Period { get; }
20 public List<decimal?> Values { get; } = new();
21 public List<decimal?> PlusDI { get; } = new();
22 public List<decimal?> MinusDI { get; } = new();
23​
24 public AverageDirectionalIndex(int period = 14)
25 {
26 if (period <= 0) throw new ArgumentOutOfRangeException(nameof(period));
27 Period = period;
28 }
29​
30 public void Calculate(IEnumerable<CandleData> candles)
31 {
32 Values.Clear(); PlusDI.Clear(); MinusDI.Clear();
33 var c = new List<CandleData>(candles);
34 if (c.Count < 2) return;
35​
36 // Initialize Lists
37 Values.Add(null);
38 PlusDI.Add(null);
39 MinusDI.Add(null);
40
41 // Accumulators for Wilder's Smoothing
42 decimal sumTR = 0, sumPDM = 0, sumMDM = 0;
43 var dxValues = new List<decimal?>(); // Intermediate DX values
44​
45 // Need at least Period + 1 items to start outputting valid ADX
46 // dxList needs to be padded to align with standard loop
47 dxValues.Add(null);
48​
49 for (int i = 1; i < c.Count; i++)
50 {
51 // 1. Compute True Range (TR)
52 decimal tr = Math.Max(c[i].High - c[i].Low, Math.Max(Math.Abs(c[i].High - c[i - 1].Close), Math.Abs(c[i].Low - c[i - 1].Close)));
53
54 // 2. Compute Directional Movement (DM)
55 decimal upMove = c[i].High - c[i - 1].High;
56 decimal downMove = c[i - 1].Low - c[i].Low;
57​
58 decimal pDM = (upMove > downMove && upMove > 0) ? upMove : 0;
59 decimal mDM = (downMove > upMove && downMove > 0) ? downMove : 0;
60​
61 // 3. Smooth TR, +DM, -DM (Wilder's Smoothing)
62 if (i < Period)
63 {
64 // Accumulation phase
65 sumTR += tr;
66 sumPDM += pDM;
67 sumMDM += mDM;
68
69 PlusDI.Add(null);
70 MinusDI.Add(null);
71 dxValues.Add(null);
72 }
73 else if (i == Period)
74 {
75 // Initial Sum
76 sumTR += tr;
77 sumPDM += pDM;
78 sumMDM += mDM;
79
80 // First +DI/-DI/DX
81 CalculateDiDx(sumTR, sumPDM, sumMDM, PlusDI, MinusDI, dxValues);
82 }
83 else
84 {
85 // Smoothing: (Prev * (N-1) + Current) / N
86 // Note: Wilder's smoothing for ADX often uses the sum form: PrevSum - (PrevSum/N) + New
87 sumTR = sumTR - (sumTR / Period) + tr;
88 sumPDM = sumPDM - (sumPDM / Period) + pDM;
89 sumMDM = sumMDM - (sumMDM / Period) + mDM;
90​
91 CalculateDiDx(sumTR, sumPDM, sumMDM, PlusDI, MinusDI, dxValues);
92 }
93 }
94​
95 // 4. Calculate ADX (Smoothed DX)
96 decimal? prevAdx = null;
97 // Align ADX loop. DX was calculated starting at index 'Period'.
98 // ADX needs another 'Period' to smooth DX.
99 // First valid DX is at index = Period.
100
101 for (int i = 0; i < dxValues.Count; i++)
102 {
103 // We need 'Period' valid DX values to create first ADX.
104 // dxValues has 'Period' nulls at start.
105 // Wait until we have processed enough DXs.
106 // A simpler approach for ADX smoothing is standard Wilder's on the DX series.
107
108 if (!dxValues[i].HasValue)
109 {
110 Values.Add(null);
111 continue;
112 }
113
114 // We need to accumulate 'Period' count of DX values first
115 if (prevAdx == null)
116 {
117 // Check if we have enough history from this point backwards?
118 // Actually, standard ADX algorithm calculates the first ADX as the average of the first N DX values.
119 // Since we are iterating strictly, we need to look back or maintain state.
120
121 // Simpler logic: Using explicit lookback for the first valid ADX
122 // First valid DX is at index [Period].
123 // We need DXs from [Period] to [Period*2 - 1].
124 int firstAdxIndex = Period * 2 - 1;
125
126 if (i < firstAdxIndex)
127 {
128 Values.Add(null);
129 }
130 else if (i == firstAdxIndex)
131 {
132 decimal s = 0;
133 for (int j = 0; j < Period; j++) s += dxValues[i - j]!.Value;
134 prevAdx = s / Period;
135 Values.Add(prevAdx);
136 }
137 }
138 else
139 {
140 prevAdx = (prevAdx * (Period - 1) + dxValues[i]!.Value) / Period;
141 Values.Add(prevAdx);
142 }
143 }
144 }
145​
146 private void CalculateDiDx(decimal tr, decimal pdm, decimal mdm, List<decimal?> pDiList, List<decimal?> mDiList, List<decimal?> dxList)
147 {
148 decimal pdi = tr != 0 ? 100 * pdm / tr : 0;
149 decimal mdi = tr != 0 ? 100 * mdm / tr : 0;
150
151 pDiList.Add(pdi);
152 mDiList.Add(mdi);
153
154 decimal sumDi = pdi + mdi;
155 decimal dx = sumDi != 0 ? 100 * Math.Abs(pdi - mdi) / sumDi : 0;
156 dxList.Add(dx);
157 }
158​
159 public static (List<decimal?> adx, List<decimal?> pdi, List<decimal?> mdi) Calculate(IEnumerable<CandleData> candles, int period = 14)
160 {
161 var a = new AverageDirectionalIndex(period);
162 a.Calculate(candles);
163 return (a.Values, a.PlusDI, a.MinusDI);
164 }
165 }
166}

1// =============================================================================
2// Logic Breakdown (AverageDirectionalIndex - ADX)
3// =============================================================================
4//
5// This document provides a "Deep Dive" into the internal logic of the
6// Average Directional Index (ADX). We explain *why* code is written this
7// way and *how* data transforms line-by-line, targeting programming beginners.
8//
9// [Core Concepts]
10// 1. ADX Theory (J. Welles Wilder, 1978)
11// ADX measures TREND STRENGTH, not direction.
12// [Why] Knowing how strong a trend is helps decide whether to use
13// trend-following or mean-reversion strategies.
14//
15// 2. ADX Interpretation
16// - 0-25: Weak or no trend (range-bound market)
17// - 25-50: Moderate trend (tradeable)
18// - 50-75: Strong trend
19// - 75-100: Extremely strong trend (rare)
20//
21// 3. Three Outputs
22// - +DI (Plus Directional Indicator): Bullish directional strength
23// - -DI (Minus Directional Indicator): Bearish directional strength
24// - ADX: Smoothed trend strength (direction-neutral)
25//
26// 4. Wilder Smoothing
27// Smoothed = Previous - (Previous / Period) + New
28// [Why] Wilder's smoothing is slower than EMA, reducing noise.
29// Period=14 Wilder ≈ Period=27 EMA in responsiveness.
30//
31// [Visual] ADX Calculation Flow:
32//
33// ┌─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
34// │ Price Data (High, Low, Close) │
35// │ │ │
36// │ ├───────────────┬────────────────┐ │
37// │ ▼ ▼ ▼ │
38// │ ┌──────────┐ ┌──────────┐ ┌──────────┐ │
39// │ │True Range│ │ +DM │ │ -DM │ │
40// │ └────┬─────┘ └────┬─────┘ └────┬─────┘ │
41// │ │ │ │ │
42// │ └───────┬──────┴───────────────┘ │
43// │ ▼ │
44// │ ┌─────────────────────┐ │
45// │ │ Wilder Smoothing │ │
46// │ └──────────┬──────────┘ │
47// │ │ │
48// │ ┌────────┼────────┐ │
49// │ ▼ │ ▼ │
50// │ ┌────────┐ │ ┌────────┐ │
51// │ │ +DI │ │ │ -DI │ = Smoothed(DM) / Smoothed(TR) × 100 │
52// │ └───┬────┘ │ └───┬────┘ │
53// │ │ │ │ │
54// │ └─────────┼───────┘ │
55// │ ▼ │
56// │ ┌──────────┐ │
57// │ │ DX │ = |+DI - -DI| / (+DI + -DI) × 100 │
58// │ └────┬─────┘ │
59// │ ▼ │
60// │ ┌─────────────────┐ │
61// │ │ Wilder Smooth │ │
62// │ └────────┬────────┘ │
63// │ ▼ │
64// │ ┌─────────┐ │
65// │ │ ADX │ (Trend Strength 0-100) │
66// │ └─────────┘ │
67// └─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘
68//
69// [Trading Signals]
70// - +DI > -DI + ADX rising: Strong uptrend
71// - -DI > +DI + ADX rising: Strong downtrend
72// - ADX < 25: Avoid trend-following strategies
73//
74// =============================================================================
75​
76using System;
77using System.Collections.Generic;
78​
79namespace TechnicalIndicators
80{
81 // =========================================================================
82 // Logic Explanation: OHLCV Data Container (CandleData)
83 // =========================================================================
84 public readonly record struct CandleData(DateTime Timestamp, decimal Open, decimal High, decimal Low, decimal Close, long Volume);
85​
86 // =========================================================================
87 // Logic Explanation: Average Directional Index
88 // =========================================================================
89 //
90 // [Why]
91 // Wilder created ADX to quantify trend strength, helping traders
92 // choose appropriate strategies (trend-following vs mean-reversion).
93 //
94 // [What]
95 // Three-component system:
96 // - +DI: Strength of upward movement
97 // - -DI: Strength of downward movement
98 // - ADX: Overall trend strength (neither bullish nor bearish)
99 //
100 // [Who]
101 // - Trend traders: Confirm trend strength before entry
102 // - System developers: Build adaptive trading strategies
103 // - Risk managers: Adjust position sizing based on trend strength
104 //
105 // -------------------------------------------------------------------------
106 public class AverageDirectionalIndex
107 {
108 // ---------------------------------------------------------------------
109 // Variable Definitions
110 // ---------------------------------------------------------------------
111 public int Period { get; }
112 public List<decimal?> Values { get; } = new(); // ADX values
113 public List<decimal?> PlusDI { get; } = new(); // +DI values
114 public List<decimal?> MinusDI { get; } = new(); // -DI values
115​
116 // =====================================================================
117 // Constructor
118 // =====================================================================
119 public AverageDirectionalIndex(int period = 14)
120 {
121 if (period <= 0) throw new ArgumentOutOfRangeException(nameof(period));
122 Period = period;
123 }
124​
125 // =====================================================================
126 // IPO: Calculate
127 // =====================================================================
128 //
129 // [Input]
130 // - candles: IEnumerable<CandleData> - OHLCV price bars
131 //
132 // [Process]
133 // 1. Calculate TR, +DM, -DM for each bar
134 // 2. Apply Wilder smoothing to get smoothed TR, +DM, -DM
135 // 3. Calculate +DI and -DI from smoothed values
136 // 4. Calculate DX from +DI and -DI
137 // 5. Apply Wilder smoothing to DX to get ADX
138 //
139 // [Output]
140 // - Populates Values (ADX), PlusDI, and MinusDI lists
141 //
142 // =====================================================================
143 public void Calculate(IEnumerable<CandleData> candles)
144 {
145 // -----------------------------------------------------------------
146 // Logic Step 1: Clear and Materialize
147 // -----------------------------------------------------------------
148 Values.Clear(); PlusDI.Clear(); MinusDI.Clear();
149 var c = new List<CandleData>(candles);
150 if (c.Count < 2) return;
151​
152 // -----------------------------------------------------------------
153 // Logic Step 2: Initial null for first bar
154 //
155 // [Why] TR/DM require two bars to calculate
156 // -----------------------------------------------------------------
157 Values.Add(null); PlusDI.Add(null); MinusDI.Add(null);
158​
159 // -----------------------------------------------------------------
160 // Variable Definitions: Wilder Smoothing Accumulators
161 // -----------------------------------------------------------------
162 decimal sumTR = 0, sumPDM = 0, sumMDM = 0;
163 var dx = new List<decimal?>();
164​
165 // =================================================================
166 // Logic Step 3: Calculate TR, +DM, -DM, +DI, -DI, DX
167 // =================================================================
168 for (int i = 1; i < c.Count; i++)
169 {
170 // -------------------------------------------------------------
171 // Logic Step 3.1: Calculate True Range
172 //
173 // [How] TR = Max(High-Low, |High-PrevClose|, |Low-PrevClose|)
174 // [Why] Captures both intraday range and gap movements
175 // -------------------------------------------------------------
176 decimal tr = Math.Max(c[i].High - c[i].Low, Math.Max(Math.Abs(c[i].High - c[i - 1].Close), Math.Abs(c[i].Low - c[i - 1].Close)));
177​
178 // -------------------------------------------------------------
179 // Logic Step 3.2: Calculate +DM and -DM
180 //
181 // [How]
182 // +DM = Today's High - Yesterday's High (if positive and > -DM)
183 // -DM = Yesterday's Low - Today's Low (if positive and > +DM)
184 //
185 // [Why] Only one direction "wins" per bar
186 // -------------------------------------------------------------
187 decimal pDM = c[i].High - c[i - 1].High > c[i - 1].Low - c[i].Low && c[i].High - c[i - 1].High > 0 ? c[i].High - c[i - 1].High : 0;
188 decimal mDM = c[i - 1].Low - c[i].Low > c[i].High - c[i - 1].High && c[i - 1].Low - c[i].Low > 0 ? c[i - 1].Low - c[i].Low : 0;
189​
190 // -------------------------------------------------------------
191 // Logic Step 3.3: Accumulation Phase (i < Period)
192 // -------------------------------------------------------------
193 if (i < Period) { sumTR += tr; sumPDM += pDM; sumMDM += mDM; PlusDI.Add(null); MinusDI.Add(null); dx.Add(null); continue; }
194​
195 // -------------------------------------------------------------
196 // Logic Step 3.4: First Wilder Smoothed Value (i == Period)
197 // -------------------------------------------------------------
198 if (i == Period) { sumTR += tr; sumPDM += pDM; sumMDM += mDM; }
199​
200 // -------------------------------------------------------------
201 // Logic Step 3.5: Subsequent Wilder Smoothing (i > Period)
202 //
203 // [How] Smoothed = Prev - (Prev/Period) + New
204 // -------------------------------------------------------------
205 else { sumTR = sumTR - sumTR / Period + tr; sumPDM = sumPDM - sumPDM / Period + pDM; sumMDM = sumMDM - sumMDM / Period + mDM; }
206​
207 // -------------------------------------------------------------
208 // Logic Step 3.6: Calculate +DI and -DI
209 //
210 // [How] DI = (Smoothed_DM / Smoothed_TR) × 100
211 // -------------------------------------------------------------
212 decimal pdi = sumTR != 0 ? 100 * sumPDM / sumTR : 0;
213 decimal mdi = sumTR != 0 ? 100 * sumMDM / sumTR : 0;
214 PlusDI.Add(pdi); MinusDI.Add(mdi);
215​
216 // -------------------------------------------------------------
217 // Logic Step 3.7: Calculate DX
218 //
219 // [How] DX = |+DI - -DI| / (+DI + -DI) × 100
220 // [Why] Measures how dominant one direction is
221 // -------------------------------------------------------------
222 decimal diSum = pdi + mdi;
223 dx.Add(diSum != 0 ? 100 * Math.Abs(pdi - mdi) / diSum : 0);
224 }
225​
226 // =================================================================
227 // Logic Step 4: Calculate ADX (Wilder Smoothed DX)
228 // =================================================================
229 decimal? adx = null;
230 for (int i = 0; i < dx.Count; i++)
231 {
232 // -------------------------------------------------------------
233 // Logic Step 4.1: Warm-up Phase
234 // -------------------------------------------------------------
235 if (i < Period - 1 || !dx[i].HasValue) { Values.Add(null); continue; }
236​
237 // -------------------------------------------------------------
238 // Logic Step 4.2: First ADX (Seed with SMA of DX)
239 // -------------------------------------------------------------
240 if (adx == null)
241 {
242 decimal s = 0; int cnt = 0;
243 for (int j = i - Period + 1; j <= i; j++) if (dx[j].HasValue) { s += dx[j]!.Value; cnt++; }
244 adx = cnt > 0 ? s / cnt : null;
245 }
246 // -------------------------------------------------------------
247 // Logic Step 4.3: Subsequent ADX (Wilder Smoothing)
248 //
249 // [How] ADX = (PrevADX × (Period-1) + DX) / Period
250 // -------------------------------------------------------------
251 else { adx = (adx * (Period - 1) + dx[i]!.Value) / Period; }
252 Values.Add(adx);
253 }
254 }
255​
256 // =====================================================================
257 // Static Convenience Wrapper
258 // =====================================================================
259 public static (List<decimal?> adx, List<decimal?> pdi, List<decimal?> mdi) Calculate(IEnumerable<CandleData> candles, int period = 14)
260 {
261 var a = new AverageDirectionalIndex(period);
262 a.Calculate(candles);
263 return (a.Values, a.PlusDI, a.MinusDI);
264 }
265 }
266}

1# =============================================================================
2# Logic Breakdown (AverageDirectionalIndex - ADX)
3# =============================================================================
4#
5# This document provides a "Deep Dive" into the internal logic of the
6# Average Directional Index. We explain *why* code is written this way
7# and *how* data transforms line-by-line, targeting programming beginners.
8#
9# [Core Concepts]
10# 1. Directional Movement (DM)
11# +DM measures upward price expansion (new highs).
12# -DM measures downward price expansion (new lows).
13# Only one can be non-zero for each bar (winner takes all).
14#
15# 2. True Range (TR)
16# The maximum of three measures capturing full volatility:
17# - High - Low (intrabar range)
18# - |High - Previous Close| (gap up detection)
19# - |Low - Previous Close| (gap down detection)
20#
21# 3. Wilder's Smoothing
22# A special EMA variant: New = Old - (Old/N) + NewValue
23# Equivalent to EMA with alpha = 1/N.
24# Used for TR, +DM, -DM, and ADX.
25#
26# 4. Directional Indicators (+DI, -DI)
27# +DI = 100 × (Smoothed +DM / Smoothed TR)
28# -DI = 100 × (Smoothed -DM / Smoothed TR)
29# Range: 0 to 100
30#
31# 5. Directional Index (DX) and ADX
32# DX = 100 × |+DI - -DI| / (+DI + -DI)
33# ADX = Smoothed DX
34# ADX measures trend STRENGTH (not direction).
35#
36# =============================================================================
37​
38​
39# -------------------------------------------------------------
40# Type-Level Explanation: AverageDirectionalIndex (class)
41#
42# [Why] Complex multi-stage calculation requiring state management.
43# Outputs three series: ADX, +DI, -DI.
44#
45# [What] Measures trend strength regardless of direction.
46# ADX > 25 typically indicates a trending market.
47# ADX < 20 typically indicates a ranging market.
48#
49# [Who] Trend-following strategies, volatility filters,
50# position sizing based on trend strength.
51#
52# [Where] Heap allocation - stores multiple output lists.
53#
54# Why separate +DI/-DI outputs?
55# While ADX measures strength, +DI/-DI indicate direction.
56# Traders use crossovers for entry signals.
57# -------------------------------------------------------------
58class AverageDirectionalIndex:
59​
60 # -------------------------------------------------------------
61 # Constructor: __init__
62 #
63 # [Why] Validate period and initialize output containers.
64 # Standard period is 14 (Wilder's recommendation).
65 #
66 # [What] period: Smoothing window for all components
67 # values: Final ADX output
68 # plus_di: +DI series
69 # minus_di: -DI series
70 # -------------------------------------------------------------
71 def __init__(self, period=14):
72​

74 # Logic Step 1: Parameter Validation
75 #
76 # [Decision]
77 # Is period valid (> 0)?
78 #
79 # [True Branch: Invalid]
80 # Raise ValueError - smoothing formulas require positive period.
81 #

86 raise ValueError("period")

88 self.period = period

95 # IPO: calculate
96 # =============================================================================
97 #
98 # [Input]
99 # - candles: list[dict] - Each dict has 'high', 'low', 'close' keys.
100 #
101 # [Process]
102 # 1. Calculate True Range and Directional Movement for each bar
103 # 2. Apply Wilder's smoothing to TR, +DM, -DM
104 # 3. Calculate +DI and -DI from smoothed values
105 # 4. Calculate DX from +DI and -DI
106 # 5. Apply Wilder's smoothing to DX to get ADX
107 #
108 # [Output]
109 # - None (results stored in values, plus_di, minus_di)
110 # =============================================================================
111 def calculate(self, candles):
112​
113 # -------------------------------------------------------------
114 # Logic Step 1: State Reset
115 # -------------------------------------------------------------
116 self.values.clear()
117 self.plus_di.clear()
118 self.minus_di.clear()
119​
120 # -------------------------------------------------------------
121 # Logic Step 2: Minimum Data Check
122 #
123 # [Decision]
124 # Do we have at least 2 candles?
125 # TR and DM require previous bar comparison.
126 # -------------------------------------------------------------
127 if len(candles) < 2:
128 return
129​
130 # Initialize first bar (no previous for comparison)
131 self.values.append(None)
132 self.plus_di.append(None)
133 self.minus_di.append(None)
134​
135 # -------------------------------------------------------------
136 # Variable Definition: Accumulators
137 #
138 # [Role]
139 # sum_tr: Running smoothed True Range
140 # sum_pdm: Running smoothed +DM
141 # sum_mdm: Running smoothed -DM
142 #
143 # [Type Choice]
144 # float - Accumulates decimal values.
145 # -------------------------------------------------------------
146 sum_tr = 0
147 sum_pdm = 0
148 sum_mdm = 0
149 dx = [] # Intermediate DX values for ADX calculation
150​
151 # -------------------------------------------------------------
152 # Logic Step 3: Main TR/DM/DI Calculation Loop
153 #
154 # [Why] (Intent)
155 # Process each bar to compute smoothed TR, +DM, -DM,
156 # then derive +DI, -DI, and DX.
157 #
158 # [Visual]
159 # Bar progression:
160 # i: 1........period period+1 period+2 ...
161 # Phase: [Accumulation] [Init DI] [Wilder Smooth]
162 # -------------------------------------------------------------
163 for i in range(1, len(candles)):
164​
165 # -------------------------------------------------------------
166 # Logic Step 3.1: Calculate True Range
167 #
168 # [Why] (Intent)
169 # TR captures full volatility including overnight gaps.
170 #
171 # [How] (Logic)
172 # TR = max(High-Low, |High-PrevClose|, |Low-PrevClose|)
173 #
174 # [Visual]
175 # Prev Close: 100
176 # Today: High=105, Low=98
177 #
178 # Option 1: 105 - 98 = 7 (intrabar)
179 # Option 2: |105 - 100| = 5 (gap up)
180 # Option 3: |98 - 100| = 2 (gap down)
181 # TR = max(7, 5, 2) = 7
182 # -------------------------------------------------------------
183 tr = max(
184 candles[i]['high'] - candles[i]['low'],
185 abs(candles[i]['high'] - candles[i - 1]['close']),
186 abs(candles[i]['low'] - candles[i - 1]['close'])
187 )
188​
189 # -------------------------------------------------------------
190 # Logic Step 3.2: Calculate Directional Movement
191 #
192 # [Why] (Intent)
193 # Identify which direction has stronger expansion.
194 #
195 # [How] (Logic)
196 # up = Today's High - Yesterday's High
197 # down = Yesterday's Low - Today's Low
198 #
199 # +DM = up if (up > down AND up > 0) else 0
200 # -DM = down if (down > up AND down > 0) else 0
201 #
202 # [Visual]
203 # Yesterday: H=100, L=95
204 # Today: H=103, L=94
205 #
206 # up = 103 - 100 = +3 (higher high)
207 # down = 95 - 94 = +1 (lower low)
208 #
209 # up > down AND up > 0 → +DM = 3, -DM = 0
210 # (Upward expansion wins)
211 # -------------------------------------------------------------
212 up = candles[i]['high'] - candles[i - 1]['high']
213 down = candles[i - 1]['low'] - candles[i]['low']
214 pdm = up if up > down and up > 0 else 0
215 mdm = down if down > up and down > 0 else 0
216​
217 # -------------------------------------------------------------
218 # Logic Step 3.3: Accumulation Phase (i < period)
219 #
220 # [Why] (Intent)
221 # Build up initial sums before first smoothed calculation.
222 # -------------------------------------------------------------
223 if i < self.period:
224 sum_tr += tr
225 sum_pdm += pdm
226 sum_mdm += mdm
227 self.plus_di.append(None)
228 self.minus_di.append(None)
229 dx.append(None)
230 continue
231​
232 # -------------------------------------------------------------
233 # Logic Step 3.4: First DI Calculation (i == period)
234 #
235 # [Why] (Intent)
236 # First smoothed values use simple sum.
237 # -------------------------------------------------------------
238 if i == self.period:
239 sum_tr += tr
240 sum_pdm += pdm
241 sum_mdm += mdm
242 else:
243 # Wilder's smoothing for subsequent bars
244 sum_tr = sum_tr - sum_tr / self.period + tr
245 sum_pdm = sum_pdm - sum_pdm / self.period + pdm
246 sum_mdm = sum_mdm - sum_mdm / self.period + mdm
247​
248 # -------------------------------------------------------------
249 # Logic Step 3.5: Calculate +DI and -DI
250 #
251 # [Why] (Intent)
252 # Normalize directional movement by volatility.
253 # This makes DI comparable across different price levels.
254 #
255 # [How] (Logic)
256 # +DI = 100 × (Smoothed +DM / Smoothed TR)
257 # -DI = 100 × (Smoothed -DM / Smoothed TR)
258 # -------------------------------------------------------------
259 pdi = 100 * sum_pdm / sum_tr if sum_tr != 0 else 0
260 mdi = 100 * sum_mdm / sum_tr if sum_tr != 0 else 0
261​
262 self.plus_di.append(pdi)
263 self.minus_di.append(mdi)
264​
265 # -------------------------------------------------------------
266 # Logic Step 3.6: Calculate DX
267 #
268 # [Why] (Intent)
269 # DX measures the difference between +DI and -DI,
270 # normalized by their sum. Range: 0 to 100.
271 #
272 # [How] (Logic)
273 # DX = 100 × |+DI - -DI| / (+DI + -DI)
274 #
275 # [Visual]
276 # +DI = 30, -DI = 10
277 # DX = 100 × |30 - 10| / (30 + 10)
278 # = 100 × 20 / 40 = 50 (strong trend)
279 # -------------------------------------------------------------
280 di_sum = pdi + mdi
281 dx.append(100 * abs(pdi - mdi) / di_sum if di_sum != 0 else 0)
282​
283 # -------------------------------------------------------------
284 # Logic Step 4: ADX Calculation Loop
285 #
286 # [Why] (Intent)
287 # ADX is the smoothed DX. It requires 'period' DX values
288 # to start, then uses Wilder's smoothing.
289 #
290 # [How] (Logic)
291 # First ADX = Simple average of first 'period' DX values
292 # Subsequent ADX = (PrevADX × (period-1) + CurrentDX) / period
293 #
294 # [Visual]
295 # DX Sequence: [... 50, 60, ... ]
296 # ADX Sequence: [... 45, 47, ... ] (Smoothing dampens volatility)
297 # -------------------------------------------------------------
298 adx = None
299​
300 for i in range(len(dx)):
301​
302 # -------------------------------------------------------------
303 # Logic Step 4.1: Insufficient Data Check
304 #
305 # [Decision]
306 # Have we reached the start of ADX calculation window?
307 #
308 # [True Branch: Skip]
309 # Append None.
310 #
311 # [False Branch: Process]
312 # Proceed to ADX calculation.
313 # -------------------------------------------------------------
314 if i < self.period - 1 or dx[i] is None:
315 self.values.append(None)
316 continue
317​
318 # -------------------------------------------------------------
319 # Logic Step 4.2: First ADX vs Smoothing
320 #
321 # [Decision]
322 # Is this the first ADX value?
323 #
324 # [True Branch: Initialization]
325 # Simple average of first 'period' DX values.
326 #
327 # [False Branch: Smoothing]
328 # Wilder's Smoothing: (Prev * (N-1) + Current) / N
329 # -------------------------------------------------------------
330 if adx is None:
331 # First ADX: Simple average of available DX values
332 s = 0
333 cnt = 0
334 for j in range(i - self.period + 1, i + 1):
335 if dx[j] is not None:
336 s += dx[j]
337 cnt += 1
338 adx = s / cnt if cnt > 0 else None
339 else:
340 # Wilder's smoothing for ADX
341 adx = (adx * (self.period - 1) + dx[i]) / self.period
342​
343 self.values.append(adx)
344​
345​
346# =============================================================================
347# Static Wrapper Function: calculate
348# =============================================================================
349#
350# [Why]
351# Provides functional API returning ADX, +DI, -DI as a tuple.
352#
353# [Pattern: 3-Step Static Wrapper]
354# =============================================================================
355def calculate(candles, period=14):
356 # 1. Instantiation
357 a = AverageDirectionalIndex(period)
358​
359 # 2. Execution
360 a.calculate(candles)
361​
362 # 3. Extraction
363 return a.values, a.plus_di, a.minus_di
